text:p.text:span: This is a rather difficult and confusing process
, but what I think I’ve settled on is the following:

text:list-item.text:p: Use Asciidoctor and .adoc files to generate a 4-pg. PDF.
Use a PyPDF2 2-up.py script to combine these 4 pgs into 2 pgs.
Done! Print this page double-sided, as the ward bulletin!
Expected process to make this work:
Manually:
Find an image, charcoalize it in LibreOffice Writer 6. Save the file. (Automate this eventually using image-processing scripts and things)
A) Type up the people doing each thing into a text document.

text:list-item.text:p: Type up all announcements in a .adoc file, with appropriate links, bold, font size, etc.
Have a script:
Rename the LibreOffice file to a .zip file or whatever, open it, and extract the image.
Parse the B) text table info, and format it according to .adoc table format.
Parse the A) text doc, and insert the people into a .adoc template.
Create 4-pgs of PDFs, including from 2 and 3 just above.

Procedure:
Use Python to replace names and content as necessary.
Zip it back up or whatever, and ensure it ends in .odt when done.
Done!

y script will then have to generate 1 new row in the table for each row I paste into the document.

text:list-item.text:p: Pick back up on the find and replace inside the extracted zip file above… (20180821, 2.3.3 and 2.3.4).

log files
have field_name/field_value/# replacements made type info logged each time you run the script.

Separate log entries with a long horizontal bar of “====”, followed by the exact date and time of running the script, and the names/paths of the input files, output files, etc.
Add a “config.py” file to contain shared configuration data, which may include project version #, input/output paths, max log size (in # lines) = 10000, etc.
Add configuration control fields as input variables (config.whatever), rather than FIELDS, to the script. Ex:
`config.fastSunday = True` will modify the bulletin to use the fastSunday version of it instead.

text:p.text:span: Add simple, stand-alone `unzip_odt` and `zip_odt` files that parse CLI filename inputs, so that a user can use these tools (instead of 7zip or whatever) to quickly unzip an odt file, do manual content.xml field fixes, and zip it back up. CANCEL THAT! THEY
DON’T DO THESE MANUAL FIXES BY EDITING THE XML FILE, THEY DO THEM IN LIBREOFFICE WRITER MANUALLY WITH THE “

text:list-item.text:p: TODO (FUTURE WORK): Extract out the core of the extract .odt, read fields input text file, find, replace, rezip, open in LibreOffice code into a new stand-alone repo, and then base this project on that repo. Call the new repo “LibreReplace”, for instance.

The benefit will be that it will get a lot more visibility and impact a lot more people that way. Think about it. LibreBulletin might only apply to 0.01% of 1% of the world (if that), but LibreReplace might eventually apply to 1% of the world. That’s a 100~1000 fold increase!
Document this “FUTURE WORK” note into the project readme!
Update the license info in the project.
Code should be LGPL
.odt docs should be CC By SA or something
NEXT (ON THE TRAIN, THEN AT HOME):

text:p.text:span: the actual find/replace in the .odt doc! See 20180821 #2.3.3-4 above!

text:list-item.text:p: Bug fix! I need to copy and reverse sort the field list in order to replace longer strings first. Ex: `self.fields.sort(reverse = True)`
newlist = oldlist.copy()
newlist.sort(reverse = True)
Consider the following fields & values:
AAA: hello
AA: goodbye
A: kiss

If you apply the find/replace of the fields in alphabetical order (A, then AA, then AAA), you’ll end up with replacing all AAA field names with “kisskisskiss”, AA field names with “kisskiss”, and no “goodbye” or “hello” field values will ever make it in! Solution: simply reverse alphabetically sort the list and do the find/replace in reverse alphabetical order. Now, it will search for the AAA field name before AA, which is before A, and you’ll end up getting all 3 field values properly into the document.

text:p.text:span: Work-around. Git commit my current changes,
the libreoffice template doc change. Then,
do a brief writeup and even video possibly on

to run a preliminary test and then use the format painter to fix broken up field name strings. Ex—perhaps they are broken up by varying formatting, so “FIELD_1” ends up becoming “FIELD” “_1” in the xml file, with each of those 2 segments having different formatting xml markup around them even though the formatting
identical in the .odt doc. Copy out the content.xml file

fixing it. Run the script and save the output, then make the changes in the .odt document, then copy out the new content.xml file, and do a diff comparison of the two via meld in order to see the differences!
Note: view xml files in Chrome!

problem though: that means I’d have to manually update announcements in a new doc, which isn’t practical, so I’m probably better off just manually doing the minor formatting to put it in “Fast Sunday” form instead????

text:p.text:span: OR, I just figure out what XML mass replacements need to take place to convert that page from normal style to Fast Sunday style, and I do that?
←-yes, I think I like this idea the best; let’s take a look at doing it!

text:list-item.text:p: YES! Do this. I just did a practice one manually and here’s how to accomplish it:

Add some manual “fields” at the beginning of the Sacrament Meeting page. Ex: “SUPER_SECRET_START”, or “SACRAMENT_MTG_START”, and at the end: “SACRAMENT_MTG_END”. Now, the XML start and end will look something like this:
<text:p text:style-name="P57">SUPER_SECRET_START</text:p>
<text:p text:style-name="P58">SUPER_SECRET_END</text:p>

So, look for these strings in the XML file, except where “P57” and “P58” can be any number, for example, and then just delete everything from START to END, and replace it with the format you’d like! Done!

TODO: image conversion optimization:

It appears that the most time-consuming part of the entire LibreBulletin script is the conversion process from one image form to another. Ex: converting a new front-cover image from .jpg to .png appears (without doing any actual timing measurements) to take ~1.5 seconds of the entire 2 second process.
So, each time you go to update an image:

text:p.text:span: Once you figure out the destination format (I suspect it’s always going to be .png), do the conversion to the destination format and
save a copy of it in the new format but with the old name
in the same location as the original file.

text:list-item.text:p: Next time you go to do the conversion, first just check to see if it’s already been done. If so, no need to repeat the conversion process every time!
In summary:

You are going to replace old_image.png with new_image.jpg. First, see if new_image.png already exists in the same folder as new_image.jpg. If so, use it and copy it onto the old_image.png with the old_image name. If not, convert it to .png, save a copy in the same dir as new_image.jpg, then do the copy and replace.
